data.text:
Dear Relebohile,

‌

Kindly find attached the approval letters for the below studies.

‌

1. A phase 2b study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of VRC01 broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibody in reducing acquisition of HIV-1 infection among men and transgender persons who have sex with men (HPTN085/ HVTN704) – **cannot locate this study on our system.**
2. Feasibility of HIV Prevention Cohort Studies among Men who have sex with Men in Sub-Saharan Africa: A study of the HIV Prevention Trials Network – Ethics reference: 141105
3. A Multi-Center, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Phase 3 Safety and Effectiveness Trial of a Vaginal Matrix Ring Containing Dapivirine for the Prevention of HIV-1 Infection in Women Microbicide Trials Network – Ethics reference: 111110
4. Phase 2B Safety and Effectiveness Study of Tenofovir 1% Gel, Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate Tablet and Emtricitabine/Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate Tablet for the Prevention of HIV Infection in Women – Ethics reference: 090408
5. A phase 2, exploratory, single center, randomized, open label, adaptive clinical trial to compare the safety and efficacy of four different experimental drug regimens to standardof care for the treatment of symptomatic outpatients with COVID-19 – Ethics reference: 200602B

‌

Best regards,

‌

‌

‌

card.desc:
Study title: Novel TB Prevention Regimens for HIV-Infected Adults

Follow up with Richard E. Chaisson, MD Professor of Medicine, Epidemiology, and International Health Director, Johns Hopkins Center for Tuberculosis Research Principal Investigator, Johns Hopkins Center for AIDS Research

N=1148

Background Treatment of latent tuberculosis in patients infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is efficacious, but few patients around the world receive such treatment. We evaluated three new regimens for latent tuberculosis that may be more potent and durable than standard isoniazid treatment. Methods We randomly assigned South African adults with HIV infection and a positive tuberculin skin test who were not taking antiretroviral therapy to receive rifapentine (900 mg) plus isoniazid (900 mg) weekly for 12 weeks, rifampin (600 mg) plus isoniazid (900 mg) twice weekly for 12 weeks, isoniazid (300 mg) daily for up to 6 years (continuous isoniazid), or isoniazid (300 mg) daily for 6 months (control group). The primary end point was tuberculosis-free survival. Results The 1148 patients had a median age of 30 years and a median CD4 cell count of 484 per cubic millimeter. Incidence rates of active tuberculosis or death were 3.1 per 100 person-years in the rifapentine–isoniazid group, 2.9 per 100 person-years in the rifampin–isoniazid group, and 2.7 per 100 person-years in the continuous-isoniazid group, as compared with 3.6 per 100 person-years in the control group (P>0.05 for all comparisons). Serious adverse reactions were more common in the continuousisoniazid group (18.4 per 100 person-years) than in the other treatment groups (8.7 to 15.4 per 100 person-years). Two of 58 isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (3.4%) were found to have multidrug resistance

‌

Wits approved

data.text:
Dear Dr. Chersich,

Thank you for resubmitting your data request. Based on the Vivli form check, we recommend a few more changes:

1. In the Research Team tab, under Additional Researchers, please update all fields for Dr. Motana.

1. Thank you for providing the list of studies you plan to analyze as an attachment. Please note that the studies included in your request are only available in the Vivli Research environment. The Summary level data may be exported and combined with external data for analysis.

a. Please note if you wanted to bring the external data into the Vivli RE, we are unable to accept data from a for-profit company without the appropriate agreements. If any of the sponsor companies are willing to share their studies with your research team via Vivli, please put us in touch directly with the company so we can help facilitate this process. Some companies may already have set ways of sharing their data so this is not always possible but we will help where we can.

b. Please clarify in the Statistical Analysis Plan if you will be exporting summary level results to combine with external data outside of the Vivli RE.

c. We have also noticed there are studies sponsored by Vivli Members in your full study list:
NCT00144183 (Boehringer Ingelheim) – this study is listed on Vivli. Please add this to your data request.

d. The following studies are not currently listed on the platform but are sponsored by Vivli members. Please fill out the enquiry form for the unlisted study here: [https://vivli.org/members/enquiries-about-studies-not-listed-on-the-vivli-platform](https://vivli.org/members/enquiries-about-studies-not-listed-on-the-vivli-platform "smartCard-inline") : NCT00069784 (Sanofi)

e. We recommend reaching out via [https://accessclinicaldata.niaid.nih.gov/](https://accessclinicaldata.niaid.nih.gov/ "smartCard-inline")  to enquire with NIAID about the availability of the following NIAID studies:
NCT02568215
NCT03164564
NCT01061151
NCT00057122
NCT00036452
NCT00705679
NCT00413725
NCT02968849
NCT02568215

f. Please submit a formal inquiry for Johnson & Johnson trials not currently listed here: [https://yoda.yale.edu/submit-inquiry](https://yoda.yale.edu/submit-inquiry "smartCard-inline")
NCT03060629
NCT03060629

If you have further questions, please feel free to contact us. Once the changes are made to the data request, please re-submit them for review. Thanks!

Regards,
The Vivli Team

card.desc:
Added as a new study based on the discussions with Ariane:

[https://www.mtnstopshiv.org/news/mtn-020-aspire](https://www.mtnstopshiv.org/news/mtn-020-aspire "smartCard-inline")

he MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial was a Phase 3, multi-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the dapivirine vaginal ring (VR) for the prevention of HIV-1 infection in healthy, sexually active, HIV-negative women. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of a dapivirine (25 mg) silicone elastomer matrix VR, inserted once every 4 weeks, in preventing HIV-1 infection and to assess its safety compared to a placebo VR.

A total of 2,629 participants were enrolled and randomized to receive either the dapivirine VR or a placebo VR. Participants used the VRs until 120 HIV-1 seroconversions were observed, with a minimum expected use of 12 months. The trial completed follow-up on June 25, 2015, and primary results were presented in February 2016, with the primary manuscript published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

**Primary Results**

The trial demonstrated that the monthly dapivirine VR was safe and effective for HIV prevention. There were no significant differences in primary safety endpoints between the study arms, and sexually transmitted infections occurred at similar rates. A total of 168 incident HIV-1 infections occurred during the product use period, with a 27% relative reduction in HIV-1 acquisition in the dapivirine ring arm compared to the placebo arm.

Subgroup analyses showed that HIV-1 protection differed significantly by age, with women ≥25 years of age demonstrating 61% protection, while those <25 years of age had no statistically significant reduction in HIV-1 incidence. Further analyses indicated that lack of HIV-1 protection and lower adherence were limited to participants ≤21 years of age.

**Study Details**

- **Protocol Chair(s):** Jared Baeten (Protocol Chair), Thesla Palanee-Phillips (Protocol Co-Chair)
- **Protocol Title:** A Multi-Center, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Phase 3 Safety and Effectiveness Trial of a Vaginal Matrix Ring Containing Dapivirine for the Prevention of HIV-1 Infection in Women
- **DAIDS Protocol ID:** 11840
- **Status:** Participants off Study and Primary Analysis Completed
- **Formulation:** Vaginal Ring
- **Drug:** Dapivirine, Placebo
- **Study Focus/Product Administration:** Vaginal
- **Study Type:** Behavioral, Efficacy, Safety
- **Study Phase:** Phase III
- **Countries:** Malawi, South Africa, Uganda, Zimbabwe
- **Population:** Women (cisgender women, non‐transgender women)
- **Funder(s):** Division of AIDS, US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, US National Institutes of Health
- **Sponsor(s):** IPM
- **Other Study Info:** Phase 3, multi-site, two-arm, randomized (1:1), double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

This summary provides an overview of the MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial, focusing on its objectives, primary results, and key details.

card.desc:
HVTN 705/HPX2008 – Soweto-Bara Clinical Research Site	 Fatima Laher		NCT03060629	HVTN 705/HPX2008

Trial title: A Study to Assess the Efficacy of a Heterologous Prime/Boost Vaccine Regimen of Ad26.Mos4.HIV and Aluminum Phosphate-Adjuvanted Clade C gp140 in Preventing Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) -1 Infection in Women in Sub-Saharan Africa
Study status: Completed
Study type: Phase 2b, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled
Study objective: To assess the preventive vaccine efficacy (VE) of a heterologous prime/boost vaccine regimen of Ad26.Mos4.HIV and aluminum phosphate-adjuvanted Clade C gp140 in preventing HIV-1 infection in HIV-seronegative women residing in sub-Saharan Africa.
Study population: HIV-seronegative women aged 18 to 45 years who were at high risk of HIV infection.
Interventions: Participants were randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments:
Vaccine regimen: Ad26.Mos4.HIV at Months 0 and 2, followed by aluminum phosphate-adjuvanted Clade C gp140 at Month 4
Placebo
Primary outcome: VE of the vaccine regimen against HIV-1 infection
Secondary outcomes:
Safety
Immunogenicity
The trial was conducted in 11 countries in sub-Saharan Africa and enrolled over 2,600 participants. The results of the trial showed that the vaccine regimen did not meet its primary endpoint of preventing HIV-1 infection. However, the vaccine regimen was found to be safe and well-tolerated.

The full results of the trial were published in the journal The Lancet in 2021. The study was funded by Janssen Vaccines & Prevention B.V., part of the Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson.

The Soweto-Bara Clinical Research Site was one of the 11 study sites in sub-Saharan Africa that participated in the HVTN 705/HPX2008 trial. The site was located in Soweto, South Africa, and was led by Dr. Fatima Laher. The site enrolled a total of 200 participants in the trial.

[https://avac.org/trial/hvtn-705-hpx2008-cr108263-imbokodo/](https://avac.org/trial/hvtn-705-hpx2008-cr108263-imbokodo/ "smartCard-inline")

card.desc:
Liz Montgomery expressed interest in sharing these data.

Here is a summary of the study "Microbicide Ring Acceptability":

The study was conducted to evaluate the acceptability and use of a vaginal microbicide ring for HIV prevention in sub-Saharan Africa. The microbicide ring is a novel method of HIV prevention that involves the use of a ring inserted into the vagina that slowly releases an antiretroviral drug to prevent HIV infection.

The study found that the ring was generally well accepted among women in sub-Saharan Africa. The participants reported that they were comfortable using the ring and that it did not interfere with their daily activities or sexual intercourse. The ring was also found to be easy to insert and remove.

However, some participants reported concerns about potential side effects and the effectiveness of the ring in preventing HIV. There were also concerns about the ring being noticeable to sexual partners.

Overall, the study concluded that while the vaginal microbicide ring is a promising tool for HIV prevention in sub-Saharan Africa, further research is needed to address the concerns raised by the participants. This includes providing more information about the safety and effectiveness of the ring, as well as strategies to ensure that the ring is used consistently and correctly.

Please note that this is a general summary and for more detailed information, you should refer to the full study.

Dr Kartik Venkatesh [kartik.venkatesh@osumc.edu](mailto:kartik.venkatesh@osumc.edu "‌")

[https://www.rti.org/publication/degrees-disclosure-study-womens-covert-use-diaphragm-mira-hiv-prevention-trial-sub-saharan-africa](https://www.rti.org/publication/degrees-disclosure-study-womens-covert-use-diaphragm-mira-hiv-prevention-trial-sub-saharan-africa "smartCard-inline")

card.desc:
Added as a new study based on the discussions with Ariane:

he MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial was a Phase 3, multi-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the dapivirine vaginal ring (VR) for the prevention of HIV-1 infection in healthy, sexually active, HIV-negative women. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of a dapivirine (25 mg) silicone elastomer matrix VR, inserted once every 4 weeks, in preventing HIV-1 infection and to assess its safety compared to a placebo VR.

A total of 2,629 participants were enrolled and randomized to receive either the dapivirine VR or a placebo VR. Participants used the VRs until 120 HIV-1 seroconversions were observed, with a minimum expected use of 12 months. The trial completed follow-up on June 25, 2015, and primary results were presented in February 2016, with the primary manuscript published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

**Primary Results**

The trial demonstrated that the monthly dapivirine VR was safe and effective for HIV prevention. There were no significant differences in primary safety endpoints between the study arms, and sexually transmitted infections occurred at similar rates. A total of 168 incident HIV-1 infections occurred during the product use period, with a 27% relative reduction in HIV-1 acquisition in the dapivirine ring arm compared to the placebo arm.

Subgroup analyses showed that HIV-1 protection differed significantly by age, with women ≥25 years of age demonstrating 61% protection, while those <25 years of age had no statistically significant reduction in HIV-1 incidence. Further analyses indicated that lack of HIV-1 protection and lower adherence were limited to participants ≤21 years of age.

**Study Details**

- **Protocol Chair(s):** Jared Baeten (Protocol Chair), Thesla Palanee-Phillips (Protocol Co-Chair)
- **Protocol Title:** A Multi-Center, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Phase 3 Safety and Effectiveness Trial of a Vaginal Matrix Ring Containing Dapivirine for the Prevention of HIV-1 Infection in Women
- **DAIDS Protocol ID:** 11840
- **Status:** Participants off Study and Primary Analysis Completed
- **Formulation:** Vaginal Ring
- **Drug:** Dapivirine, Placebo
- **Study Focus/Product Administration:** Vaginal
- **Study Type:** Behavioral, Efficacy, Safety
- **Study Phase:** Phase III
- **Countries:** Malawi, South Africa, Uganda, Zimbabwe
- **Population:** Women (cisgender women, non‐transgender women)
- **Funder(s):** Division of AIDS, US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, US National Institutes of Health
- **Sponsor(s):** IPM
- **Other Study Info:** Phase 3, multi-site, two-arm, randomized (1:1), double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

This summary provides an overview of the MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial, focusing on its objectives, primary results, and key details.

data.text:
Hi Craig,

‌

We had some unexpected work needed on another dataset, but I am hopeful that the HPTN 052 datasets should be ready in a month or so. I will prioritize completion of the work on the de-identified datasets from that study.

‌

**HPTN 084 is an ongoing study, so we are unable to release data for that study. We expect that study to be ongoing for another couple of years – it seems it will go on forever** 😊

‌

Thanks for checking in,

‌

\-Lynda

card.desc:
VOICE trial and some PMTCT data

The VOICE PMTCT trial was a clinical research study led by Dr. Sharon Hillier that aimed to evaluate different methods of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in sub-Saharan Africa. PMTCT stands for "Prevention of Mother-To-Child Transmission" of HIV.

The trial was conducted between 2009 and 2012 and enrolled 5,029 HIV-negative women from South Africa, Uganda, and Zimbabwe who were at high risk of acquiring HIV. The participants were randomly assigned to one of five study groups: three groups received different HIV prevention methods (daily oral tablets of either tenofovir, Truvada, or tenofovir plus emtricitabine), one group received a placebo pill, and one group received a vaginal gel containing tenofovir.

The primary objective of the trial was to determine the safety and efficacy of these methods in preventing HIV transmission from mother to child during breastfeeding. However, the trial results showed that none of the methods tested were effective in reducing HIV transmission rates.

Despite these disappointing results, the VOICE PMTCT trial provided valuable insights into the challenges of implementing effective HIV prevention strategies in resource-limited settings. Dr. Hillier and her team continue to conduct important research on HIV prevention and treatment, including ongoing studies of long-acting antiretroviral drugs and novel strategies for preventing HIV transmission.

‌

NB: Thes requires HREC approval for secondary analysis. This request applies to VOICE, HOPE and ASPIRE
card.name: JHB_PHRU_31_VOICE_PMTCT

The primary objective of the trial was to determine the safety and efficacy of these methods in preventing HIV transmission from mother to child during breastfeeding. However, the trial results showed that none of the methods tested were effective in reducing HIV transmission rates.

data.text:
Lisa Levy  shared response looped from prior discussions:Dear  HE²AT  Team and MTN (FHI, Wits and SCHARP) reps:

‌

I am pulling different email threads and folks into one, to streamline the conversation re: access of MTN longitudinal datasets from Joburg sites (VOICE and possibly ASPIRE and HOPE) for the HEAT secondary analysis:

‌

1. Lisa Levy and I had a call recently with Sharon Hillier (PI of MTN) and DAIDS and we addressed the initial question of access to the Joburg data from MTN trials.  Here is the outcome of that discussion-

              a. MTN is no longer accepting ancillary study or data requests due to lack of time/bandwidth and funds. HOWEVER…

              b. Local sites (like the Wits RHI site) have received their own site datasets and these are available to be shared.    IMPORTANTLY, the local sites datasets, do NOT need SCHARP involvement or MTN leadership or DAIDS approval. So this is the way to go to simplify access of data between the MTN WitsRHI site and the HEAT Team. 

‌

1. I contacted  Thes who has been in touch with Matt, Craig and others from the HEAT team, letting them know that this data request for MTN data went full circle and is back on her laps. Thes said that Krina (copied on the TO line) is the POC for this request. 

              a. Thes also wrote back saying that first she/the site would need **IRB approval** for the HEAT secondary analysis, and then the datasets could be provided to the HEAT Team. 

              b. We also noted that the requests from the HEAT team had changed over time. When I interacted with HEAT at the end of august/early September, I was told that they needed => 200 participants, followed longitudinally, with Lab, clinical and AE data and from the JOBURG area. Further geolocalisation data was welcomed but not indispensable. Therefore I mentioned to the HEAT Team that both VOICE and ASPIRE/HOPE trials had an adequate Joburg sample size and longitudinal data that could be used, if participants’ locator wasn’t a requirement. 

              c. If/when you get access to the MTN data, and when you published your HEAT results, an acknowledgment of NIAD/DAIDS and the MTN would be appropriate in the acknowledgment section, but the results/findings of your analysis do NOT need to be reviewed or approved by MTN or DAIDS. 

‌

Based on these 2 points, it seems like the way forward is to let the folks at WitsRHI (MTN site reps and HEAT team) sort out what are the next steps, and to leave out of this conversation all in the cc line- that is reps from SCHARP, FHI360 (and MTN leadership). 

I am happy to stay involved if at all helpful, but I can also be dropped if the next steps would not benefit from my involvement. 

‌

**PS- for the HEAT Team**: I am still trying to connect with Ali Minnis at RTI to clarify possible access to TRIO and MIRA datasets.. I will continue to try, and will let you know the outcome of our discussion once I am able to get a call with ALi. 

‌

Lisa or others, please feel free to chime in if I forgot anything. 

‌

Best, Ariane

data.text:
Dear Dr. Chersich,

Thank you for sending the revisions on your data request. Based on the Vivli Admin form check, we recommend a few more changes to your data request:

1. Please elaborate on Dr. Jack’s relevant skills or prior experience in performing similar statistical analyses as planned (e.g. previous publications) and include the statement that Dr. Jack acted as the statistician on at least one peer-reviewed publication with a similar methodological approach as your analysis. Please include their publications where they acted as a statistician (or CV) in the attachments tab.

1. A Vivli admin has revised the lay summary to include background information from the first draft, and simplified the wording and technical descriptions so it is suitable for a lay audience, as well as added a brief description of HIV and HIV population vulnerabilities to heat. Please review.

1. We noticed that you will be performing a meta-analysis. Please include the following information:

a. Please also provide the full details of all studies that you are going to analyze. You may provide the list either as an attachment or in the “Other Information” section and should include NCT or sponsor id, description of the study, and study sponsor.
b. Please also clarify if you will be bringing these studies into the Vivli research environment or if you are planning to conduct the analyses outside of the Vivli research environment and then combine the summary-level results.

data.text:
Dear Dr. Chersich,

Thank you for sending the revisions on your data request. Based on the Vivli Admin form check, we recommend a few more changes to your data request:

1. Please elaborate on Dr. Jack’s relevant skills or prior experience in performing similar statistical analyses as planned (e.g. previous publications) and include the statement that Dr. Jack acted as the statistician on at least one peer-reviewed publication with a similar methodological approach as your analysis. Please include their publications where they acted as a statistician (or CV) in the attachments tab.

1. A Vivli admin has revised the lay summary to include background information from the first draft, and simplified the wording and technical descriptions so it is suitable for a lay audience, as well as added a brief description of HIV and HIV population vulnerabilities to heat. Please review.

1. We noticed that you will be performing a meta-analysis. Please include the following information:

a. Please also provide the full details of all studies that you are going to analyze. You may provide the list either as an attachment or in the “Other Information” section and should include NCT or sponsor id, description of the study, and study sponsor.
b. Please also clarify if you will be bringing these studies into the Vivli research environment or if you are planning to conduct the analyses outside of the Vivli research environment and then combine the summary-level results.

For additional guidance on completing your data request form, please see our video here: [https://youtu.be/Kt_ECYv2Mi8](https://youtu.be/Kt_ECYv2Mi8 "smartCard-inline")
A comprehensive listing of the software and R packages available in the Vivli Research Environment can be reviewed here: [https://vivli.org/resources/vivli-secure-research-environment/](https://vivli.org/resources/vivli-secure-research-environment/ "smartCard-inline")

If you have further questions, please feel free to contact us. Once the changes are made to the data request, please re-submit them for review. Thanks!

Regards,
The Vivli Team

card.desc:
Title: Hepatitis B Viral (Hbv) Infection

PI: Cynthia Finhaber

NB: Ian indicated that this data is nested in the Themba Lethu dataset. We will archive this card if this is confirmed.

‌

The main hypothesis of the study was to determine the prevalence of occult HBV infection in HIV-positive people in South Africa using sensitive molecular techniques for detecting HBV DNA in serum .

The study does not provide information about the age of the participants. However, it reports that 502 patients attending an urban hospital were screened for HBV using serological testing for HBsAg, core antibody (anti-HBc), and surface antibody (anti-HBs). DNA was analyzed using real-time quantitative PCR to determine the HBV viral load.

‌

doi: 10.1016/j.ijid.2008.08.018

[Occult hepatitis B virus infection in patients with isolated core antibody and HIV co-infection in an urban clinic in Johannesburg, South Africa - ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971208015415 "‌")

‌

The study, titled "A Phase IIb, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of the Safety and Immunogenicity of Ad26.Mos4.HIV in HIV-1-Negative Adults in South Africa," was published in the journal AIDS in 2008. The study was conducted by researchers from the University of KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa and the University of California, San Francisco.

The study enrolled 398 HIV-1-negative adults in South Africa. Participants were randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments:

Ad26.Mos4.HIV, a vaccine that is designed to elicit a strong immune response against HIV-1
Placebo
The primary outcome of the study was the safety of Ad26.Mos4.HIV. The study found that Ad26.Mos4.HIV was safe and well-tolerated. The most common side effects were mild and included injection site pain, fever, and fatigue.

The secondary outcome of the study was the immunogenicity of Ad26.Mos4.HIV. The study found that Ad26.Mos4.HIV elicited a strong immune response against HIV-1. The vaccine was able to generate antibodies that could neutralize HIV-1.

The study did not provide any data on how to access the data. However, the study was funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the NIH has a policy of making data from NIH-funded studies available to the public. Therefore, it is likely that the data from this study is available to the public.

card.desc:
Study title: Novel TB Prevention Regimens for HIV-Infected Adults

Follow up with Richard E. Chaisson, MD Professor of Medicine, Epidemiology, and International Health Director, Johns Hopkins Center for Tuberculosis Research Principal Investigator, Johns Hopkins Center for AIDS Research

N=1148

Background Treatment of latent tuberculosis in patients infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is efficacious, but few patients around the world receive such treatment. We evaluated three new regimens for latent tuberculosis that may be more potent and durable than standard isoniazid treatment. Methods We randomly assigned South African adults with HIV infection and a positive tuberculin skin test who were not taking antiretroviral therapy to receive rifapentine (900 mg) plus isoniazid (900 mg) weekly for 12 weeks, rifampin (600 mg) plus isoniazid (900 mg) twice weekly for 12 weeks, isoniazid (300 mg) daily for up to 6 years (continuous isoniazid), or isoniazid (300 mg) daily for 6 months (control group). The primary end point was tuberculosis-free survival. Results The 1148 patients had a median age of 30 years and a median CD4 cell count of 484 per cubic millimeter. Incidence rates of active tuberculosis or death were 3.1 per 100 person-years in the rifapentine–isoniazid group, 2.9 per 100 person-years in the rifampin–isoniazid group, and 2.7 per 100 person-years in the continuous-isoniazid group, as compared with 3.6 per 100 person-years in the control group (P>0.05 for all comparisons). Serious adverse reactions were more common in the continuousisoniazid group (18.4 per 100 person-years) than in the other treatment groups (8.7 to 15.4 per 100 person-years). Two of 58 isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (3.4%) were found to have multidrug resistance

‌

Wits approved

card.desc:
Study title: An Evaluation of Strategies to Accelerate Entry-into-care following HIV Diagnosis
among Adults in Gauteng and Limpopo Provinces, South Africa

N=1250

‌

Dear all,

‌

I wanted to share a summary of our recent productive meeting with Salome Charalambous and Chris Hoffman, where we discussed the Heat Center project. The project aims to understand the relationship between climate data (primarily temperature) and health data in Johannesburg and Abhijan. The project requires clinical trial and cohort data sets from 2000-2022 with geolocation information, demographic information, lab data, and blood samples.

‌

During the meeting, we covered the following topics:

1. The Heat Center project: I introduced the project, outlining its main aims and the data needed.
2. Finding relevant studies: Salome and I discussed potential studies that might contribute to the project, including TB trials (especially Rifaquin), COVID trials, and HIV trials.
3. Data sharing and governance: We also talked about the process of obtaining and sharing the data, such as legal agreements and privacy assurances.

‌

The way forward for this project is as follows:

1. Identify studies with relevant data: Salome and I will work together to find suitable databases before proceeding further with the project.
2. Data sharing process: We will engage with our legal teams and data holders to establish data transfer or data sharing agreements.
3. Address potential issues: The team will discuss any concerns, such as capturing addresses electronically, with the data sharing committee before making any decisions.

‌

As an action item, I will send the presentation to Salome for the upcoming data governance meeting. In the meantime, Salome will consult with her team to determine which databases would be most suitable for the project. An intern will also be involved in moving things forward.

‌

Thank you all for your commitment to this project. We look forward to working together to achieve our goals and will keep you updated on our progress.

Best regards,
card.name: JHB_Aurum_009_Tholimpilo

old.desc: Background Mortality remains high among individuals with HIV in South Africa largely due to low CD4 at initiation of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) or failure to initiate cART altogether. The problem of advanced HIV at the time of entry-into-care persists despite increases in CD4 count initiation thresholds and higher CD4 counts among individuals testing HIV positive at HIV counseling and testing services (HCT). A reason for the discord between CD4 at HCT and CD4 at cART initiation is a failure to effectively link people who test positive into HIV care; less than half of individuals testing HIV positive enter HIV care within 3-6 month of HIV diagnosis. However, not only do these delays increase HIV associated mortality, delays from testing positive to entry-into-care for HIV also reduces the ability of test-and-treat strategies to reduce HIV transmission through HIV treatment. Objectives The main objective of this study is to compare the effectiveness of combinations of three patient-oriented strategies, compared to the standard of care, to increase the proportion of patients who enter-into-care for HIV within 90 days of testing HIV positive. Study design We are proposing an open (non-masked) individually-randomized implementation science evaluation of the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of combinations of three strategies to increase timely entry-into-care for HIV compared to the standard of care. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four arms to increase timely entry into care: (1) standard of care, (2) point-of-care CD4 and transport assistance, (3) point-of-care CD4 and care facilitator and (4) point-of-care CD4, transport assistance, and care facilitator. We require 560 participants per arm, and to allow for loss from moving away from the study area or withdrawal from the study, we propose a sample size of 625 per arm for a total of 2500 subjects. Study activities will be conducted over a period of 3 years, from 12 July 2012 to 11 July 2015. Study setting The proposed project will be built onto the current community-based HCT (mobile and fixed) services offered by Aurum. We plan to include six HCT teams, 3 operating in Ekurhuleni District (Gauteng Province) and 3 in Limpopo. The HCT units serve peri-urban townships and informal settlements, rural farm workers, and both urban and rural communities Significance The proposed project takes an innovative and comprehensive approach in targeting each of the key entry-into-care barrier domains. In addition, it will provide critical effectiveness, costing and cost effectiveness data to inform policy. These results will be highly relevant to the Government of South Africa in setting policy to achieve specific care, cART, and HIV prevention goals set out in the 2012-2016 South African National Strategic Plan.

data.text: Broad consent is applied for this study. Participants are given a choice permit or decline the use of their samples/information to be used outside of this study. In this case the participants that have declined their data would not be made available for further research beyond HPTN. “14. When samples are no longer needed for this study, the study sponsors want to keep them for use in other studies by HVTN, HPTN, or other researchers. We will call these “extra samples.” This section gives you information so you can decide if you want your extra samples and information used in other studies. You will mark your decision at the end of the form. If you have any questions, please ask. Do I have to agree? No. You are free to say yes or no, or to change your mind after you sign this form. At your request, we will destroy all extra samples that we have. Your decision will not affect your being in this study or have any negative consequences here. Where are the samples stored? Extra samples are stored in a secure central place called a repository. Your samples will be stored in the HVTN repository in the United States. How long will the samples be stored? There is no limit on how long your extra samples will be stored. [Site: insert limits if your regulatory authority imposes them.] Will I be paid for the use of my samples? No. Also, a researcher may make a new scientific discovery or product based on the use of your samples. If this happens, there is no plan to share any money with you. The researcher is not likely to ever know who you are. Will I benefit from allowing my samples to be used in other studies? Probably not. Results from these other studies are not given to you, this clinic, or your doctor. They are not needed for your medical care. They are not part of your medical record. The studies are only being done for research purposes. Will the HVTN or HPTN sell my samples and information? No, but the HVTN and HPTN may share your samples with other researchers. Once we share your samples and information, we will not be able to get them back. How do other researchers get my samples and information? When a researcher wants to use your samples and/or information, their research plan must be approved by the HVTN and HPTN. Also, the researcher’s institutional review board (IRB) or ethics committee (EC) will review their plan. [Site: If review by your institution’s IRB/EC/RE is also required, insert a sentence stating this.] IRBs/ECs protect the rights and well-being of people in research. If the research plan is approved, the HVTN and HPTN will send your samples to the researcher’s location. What information is shared with other researchers? The samples and limited information will be labeled with a code number. Your name will not be part of the information. However, some information that we share may be personal, such as your race, ethnicity, gender, health information from the study, and HIV status. We may share information about the study product you received and how your body responded to the study product. What kind of studies might be done with my extra samples and information? The studies will be related to HIV prevention or infection, the immune system, and other diseases. Researchers may also do genetic testing on your samples.

card.desc:
1. **Purpose and Establishment**: The Themba Lethu Clinical Cohort was set up to facilitate large patient-level analyses from a single HIV treatment site. Its primary goal is to evaluate National Treatment Guidelines in South Africa and address questions of national and international policy relevance. It integrates economic and epidemiological perspectives into HIV research​​​​.
2. **Location and Impact**: The cohort is based at the Helen Joseph Hospital in Johannesburg. It has significantly contributed to understanding the effectiveness of HIV treatment rollout. This contribution is not only local but also extends to broader regional and national evaluations, particularly through collaborations with the International Epidemiologic Database to Evaluate AIDS (IeDEA)​​.
3. **Patient Demographics and Results**: Over time, the Themba Lethu Clinical Cohort has grown significantly. It started with less than 2,000 patients in 2004/2005 and expanded to more than 9,000 patients. The cohort, at one point, included over 13,000 patients, demonstrating positive outcomes in terms of mortality, lost to follow-up (LTF), viral suppression, and other factors over the years​​.

data.text:
The ASPIRE MTN020 study, officially known as "A Study to Prevent Infection with a Ring for Extended Use," was a significant Phase III clinical trial aimed at determining the efficacy and safety of a vaginal ring containing the antiretroviral (ARV) drug dapivirine in preventing the sexual transmission of HIV. The study was conducted across various sites in Malawi, South Africa, Uganda, and Zimbabwe between 2012 and 2015. It enrolled 2,629 sexually active HIV-negative women aged 18-45, with a significant portion (1,426) from South Africa​​​​.

The results of the ASPIRE study, reported in 2016, showed that the dapivirine ring reduced the risk of HIV infection by 27 percent overall. However, a more profound impact was observed among specific age groups. Women older than 21 experienced a 56 percent reduction in HIV risk, with those 25 and older showing a 61 percent lower likelihood of acquiring HIV compared to their counterparts in the placebo group. This heightened efficacy in older age groups was attributed to more consistent usage of the ring. On the other hand, the ring showed little to no protective effect in women aged 18-21, possibly due to lower adherence levels in this age group​​​​.

Interestingly, the study found no significant differences in HIV protection by country, indicating that the dapivirine ring's efficacy was consistent across different geographical contexts, including the South African sites​​.

Furthermore, qualitative insights from the trial participants revealed the importance of peer influence on the acceptability and adherence to the ring. Women developed strong interpersonal connections during the trial, and those who knew each other prior to joining the study had a stronger influence on each other's adherence. However, external peers often provided negative input about the ring and study, sometimes leading to ring removals. This highlights the complex interplay of social dynamics in clinical trial participation and adherence to biomedical interventions​​.

In summary, the ASPIRE MTN020 study demonstrated the potential of the dapivirine vaginal ring as a female-initiated HIV prevention method, especially in older age groups. It also underscored the significance of adherence and the influence of social networks on the success of such interventions.

data.text:
1. I contacted  Thes who has been in touch with Matt, Craig and others from the HEAT team, letting them know that this data request for MTN data went full circle and is back on her laps. Thes said that Krina (copied on the TO line) is the POC for this request.
    a. Thes also wrote back saying that first she/the site would need IRB approval for the HEAT secondary analysis, and then the datasets could be provided to the HEAT Team.
    b. We also noted that the requests from the HEAT team had changed over time. When I interacted with HEAT at the end of august/early September, I was told that they needed => 200 participants, followed longitudinally, with Lab, clinical and AE data and from the JOBURG area. Further geolocalisation data was welcomed but not indispensable. Therefore I mentioned to the HEAT Team that both VOICE and ASPIRE/HOPE trials had an adequate Joburg sample size and longitudinal data that could be used, if participants’ locator wasn’t a requirement.
    c. If/when you get access to the MTN data, and when you published your HEAT results, an acknowledgment of NIAD/DAIDS and the MTN would be appropriate in the acknowledgment section, but the results/findings of your analysis do NOT need to be reviewed or approved by MTN or DAIDS.

data.text:
1. I contacted  Thes who has been in touch with Matt, Craig and others from the HEAT team, letting them know that this data request for MTN data went full circle and is back on her laps. Thes said that Krina (copied on the TO line) is the POC for this request. 

              a. Thes also wrote back saying that first she/the site would need **IRB approval** for the HEAT secondary analysis, and then the datasets could be provided to the HEAT Team. 

              b. We also noted that the requests from the HEAT team had changed over time. When I interacted with HEAT at the end of august/early September, I was told that they needed => 200 participants, followed longitudinally, with Lab, clinical and AE data and from the JOBURG area. Further geolocalisation data was welcomed but not indispensable. Therefore I mentioned to the HEAT Team that both VOICE and ASPIRE/HOPE trials had an adequate Joburg sample size and longitudinal data that could be used, if participants’ locator wasn’t a requirement. 

              c. If/when you get access to the MTN data, and when you published your HEAT results, an acknowledgment of NIAD/DAIDS and the MTN would be appropriate in the acknowledgment section, but the results/findings of your analysis do NOT need to be reviewed or approved by MTN or DAIDS.

data.text:
**Response to Vivli for Data Request ID "00009234"**

Dear Vivli Team,

We appreciate the thorough review of our data request and the opportunity to provide the additional information required for the "Developing data science solutions to mitigate the health impacts of climate change in Africa: The Heat and Health African Transdisciplinary Center (HE²AT Center)" project.

1. **Statistical Expertise of Dr. Chris Jack:** Dr. Chris Jack from the Climate System Analysis Group at the University of Cape Town will serve as the project's lead statistician. Dr. Jack's extensive background in climate science modeling and application of data science methodologies aligns perfectly with the project's analytical framework. His previous work in developing the CSAG/UCT Jupyter Hub and his contribution to IBM PAIRS showcases his proficiency in handling complex data sets and performing rigorous statistical analysis.
2. **Software and Compute Environment:** Our project utilizes a comprehensive array of statistical and machine learning software packages, including TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras, Scikit-learn, Numpy, Scipy, and Pandas, ensuring the use of state-of-the-art analytical techniques. These tools are integral to our data analysis and are readily available to HE2AT Center analysts, reflecting our commitment to technical precision and innovation in research​​.
3. **Dissemination and Publication Plan:** We aim to submit our research findings to high-impact journals that cater to an interdisciplinary audience interested in the intersections of climate science, public health, and data science. Potential journals for publication include "The Lancet Planetary Health," "Environmental Health Perspectives," and "Journal of Climate Change and Health." Conferences such as the International Society for Environmental Epidemiology (ISEE) and the American Public Health Association (APHA) Annual Meeting also form part of our dissemination strategy.
4. **Data Sharing Policies and Anonymization Standards:** We adhere to robust data sharing and anonymization standards, ensuring the safeguarding of participant confidentiality. Our data management protocols, executed by the DMAC team on the CSAG/UCT data platform, are designed to be in strict compliance with ethical research standards and intellectual property rights, consistent with the policies of both Vivli and our data contributors​​.
5. **Plain Language Summary for Research Proposal:** Our project aims to use advanced data analysis to understand how rising temperatures affect health outcomes in African cities and to develop an Early Warning System to inform communities about high-heat risks. The selection of HIV-related studies for analysis is based on the unique vulnerabilities of HIV-positive individuals to extreme heat, providing crucial insights into urban heat-health dynamics.
6. **Additional Information Requested by Vivli:** We have updated the Research Team tab with comprehensive details for Dr. Motana and provided a clearer narrative summary in the Research Proposal tab, removing technical jargon for accessibility. We have also adjusted our Target Analysis Start Date and Estimated Analysis Completion Date to fit within the 2-5 month timeline provided by Vivli for the approval and data uploading process.
7. **Statistical Analysis Plan:** In our Statistical Analysis Plan, we have outlined our approach to handling missing data, which will be managed through multiple imputation techniques to preserve data integrity. The rationale for selecting studies is rooted in achieving a representative understanding of heat-health impacts across diverse urban settings in Africa. In our meta-analysis, we will use a mixed-effects model framework to maintain the independence of each study while accounting for between-study variability

Thanks for your email. I have taken over managing the auxiliary studies and Nicole has transitioned into a different position here at Fred Hutch.

‌

I have begun the process of receiving approvals for HVTN 702, 703, 503. Currently I am getting approvals from the protocol team leadership, and should have that by next week. Once I finish with that approval, 702 has an extra set of approvals that I will have to get, which will likely take another week or so. Thank you,

Sydney

data.text:
Hi Relebohile,

‌

Thanks for your email. I have taken over managing the auxiliary studies and Nicole has transitioned into a different position here at Fred Hutch.

‌

I have begun the process of receiving approvals for HVTN 702, 703, 503. Currently I am getting approvals from the protocol team leadership, and should have that by next week. Once I finish with that approval, 702 has an extra set of approvals that I will have to get, which will likely take another week or so. From there, your proposal will move onto regulatory approval and you should be hearing from them. I will keep you updated once I receive protocol team leadership approval.

‌

Please let me know if you have any other questions. Happy to go over any of this in further detail.

‌

Thank you,

Sydney

list.name: Expressed interest in participating/Next steps email or address queries on application

data.text:
Hi Relebohile,

‌

We received some feedback from the protocol team leadership. Please let me know your response to the below:

- _I’m supportive that climate health research be done but did the feasibility committee have any feedback about the feasibility of some of these data requests?_
  - _These data were not collected: signs of dehydration, CD4, HDL, LDL, cholesterol. I haven’t cross-checked all variables across all trials so there could be more, and perhaps some data were not collected in a standardised way across all participants._
  - _The trials had never obtained consent to enter specific geo-identifiers (location of participant - not sure how this differs from household address) as data, and the consent forms never informed participants about geo-identifiers. The trial site is the only geo-identifier that is entered as data._

_Which sites specifically in Johannesburg? Have those PIs been asked/invited because the proposal should reflect that. Specifically those PIs would need to have their sites submit the proposal to their ethics committee_

Received approval Date:   27 October 2023

‌

To:       Prof. Matthew Chersich, University of the _Witwatersrand (Wits), Research Professor_

Prof. Lee Fairlie, _Wits Reproductive Health and HIV Institute,_ Director of Maternal

and Child Health

‌

From:   Dr. Judith Currier, ACTG Principal Investigator and Executive Committee (AEC) Chair

Dr. Joseph Eron, ACTG Scientific Agenda Steering Committee Chair and AEC Vice Chair

‌

‌

Thank you for providing the Wits Human Research Ethics Committee’s approval for The HE2AT Center Research Project 2 and for addressing each of the points outlined in our memorandum of 31 May. In addition, we are equally pleased that Prof Sanne is working with you, including reaching out to the CDC regarding A5349 data and to the IMPAACT Network for data collected at the Network’s Soweto clinical research site.

‌

Given your reply below, on 13 October, we approved DR 088 on behalf of the ACTG Network Leadership Steering Committee.

‌

Please be advised this DR requires a signed ACTG Specimen and/or Data Usage Acknowledgement (SDUA) before data are released. The ACTG Leadership and Operations Center (LOC) will forward the SDUA form to the proposing investigators.

‌

We appreciate the project update Mr. Craig Parker provided on 4 October. We wish you the best with your planned analyses and manuscripts. Attached is the ACTG’s standard operating procedure “Publications and Disclosure of Study Results” (ACTG-111) for your reference.

‌

You may send any further replies or questions for the Network Leadership to [ACTGLeadershipSupport@dlhcorp.com](mailto:ACTGLeadershipSupport@dlhcorp.com "‌").

card.desc:
CHRU - Clinical HIV Research Unit, PI Ian Sanne

Clinical HIV Research Unit (CHRU)Johannesburg, Westdene, South Africa, 2092

Controlled Comparison of Two Moxifloxacin Containing Treatment Shortening Regimens in Pulmonary Tuberculosis

[https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00864383?term=Two+Months+Ethambutol%2C+Isoniazid%2C+Rifampicin+and+Pyrazinamide&cntry=ZA&draw=2&rank=1](https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00864383?term=Two+Months+Ethambutol%2C+Isoniazid%2C+Rifampicin+and+Pyrazinamide&cntry=ZA&draw=2&rank=1 "‌")

‌

Research Officer: Goldberg, Stefan (CDC/DDID/NCIRD/OD) (CTR) [ssg3@cdc.gov](mailto:ssg3@cdc.gov "‌") (Retired) new Research Officer at CDC Kurbatova, Ekaterina (CDC/DDID/NCHHSTP/DTE) [ies3@cdc.gov](mailto:ies3@cdc.gov "‌")

NCT00864383

Study Type :Interventional  (Clinical Trial)Actual Enrollment :1931

Number of Locations: 47 Locations

Clinical HIV Research Unit (CHRU)Johannesburg, Westdene, **South Africa**, 2092

Study Title: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind Trial Comparing Different Drug Combinations for Treating Adult Pulmonary Tuberculosis

Study Design: Participants are randomly assigned to different treatment groups in a parallel manner. The study is quadruple-masked, meaning that the participant, care provider, investigator, and outcome assessor are all unaware of the treatment group assignments. The main goal of the study is to compare the effectiveness of different treatment regimens.

Treatment Comparison:

A two-month intensive phase comparing a combination of Ethambutol, Moxifloxacin, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide to the standard regimen (Ethambutol, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide).

A treatment shortening regimen comparing two months of Moxifloxacin, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide followed by two months of Moxifloxacin, Isoniazid, and Rifampicin to the standard regimen (two months of Ethambutol, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, and Pyrazinamide followed by four months of Isoniazid and Rifampicin).

Important Dates:

Study started in January 2008
Primary completion in October 2013
Study completed in February 2014

data.text:
Dear Stefan,

Thank you for linking.

‌

Dear Relebohile,

Thank you for your interest in S31/A5349 data. We are currently working on transition trial data to the data sharing platform that will make data publicly available, but at this time we are unable to complete this data sharing request.

‌

Best regards,
Katya Kurbatova, Ekaterina [ies3@cdc.gov](mailto:ies3@cdc.gov "‌")

list.name: 3rd Invite sent

data.text: @craigparker15 we need to request this data through CDC”The study A5349 (“Rifapentine-Containing Treatment Shortening Regimens for Pulmonary Tuberculosis”) was conducted in collaboration with the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the CDC was the sponsor. Therefore, the ACTG is not in a position to approve use of data from this study, and you should contact the A5349 Program Officer, Dr. Stefan Goldberg, at the CDC Tuberculosis Trials Consortium (TBTC) Data Center.

data.text:
Response from Vivli: As part of your participation in the Vivli platform, you have been or will be involved in a DataRequest titled "Developing data science solutions to mitigate the health impacts of climate change in Africa: The Heat and Health African Transdisciplinary Center (HE²AT Center)" with id "00009234".

User Sarah Sweet has entered additional information or a question into the Open chat on that DataRequest.

The content of the chat message follows:

Dear Dr. Chersich,

Based on the Vivli Admin form check, we recommend the following changes to the data request:

1. Please elaborate on Dr. Parker’s relevant skills or prior experience in performing similar statistical analyses as planned (e.g. previous publications) and include the statement that Dr. Parker acted as the statistician on at least one peer-reviewed publication with a similar methodological approach as your analysis. Please include their publications where they acted as a statistician (or CV) in the attachments tab.

1. In the Research Team tab, under Additional Researchers, please update all fields for Dr. Motana.

1. In the Research Proposal tab, please simplify the narrative/plain language summary so that is suitable for a non-scientific or lay audience. Please remove any technical or field-specific language, such as “anthropogenic climate change” and “geospatial analysis”. Please include additional information regarding:

a. A brief description on why HIV related study was selected for this project
b. How the research will be conducted; (i.e. briefly describe what design and methods you have you chosen and why)

For additional guidance on writing your narrative summary, please see our video here: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KVIgV4lugDg](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KVIgV4lugDg "smartCard-inline")

Please note that this field is published on the Vivli website if the request is approved.

1. We anticipate that working through the approval process, signing the DUA, and uploading the data may take between 2-5 months. Please use this timeline as a guideline to adjust your Target Analysis Start Date and Estimated Analysis Completion Date, if necessary.

1. In the Research Proposal tab, please update your Dissemination and Publication Plan to include possible journals or conferences you plan to submit your research findings with the statement declarative of your intention to publish your research findings (e.g. ”We plan to submit our research findings to journals targeted at X scientific community such as \_\_\_\_\_\__.”)

1. In the Statistical Analysis Plan field, please elaborate how the analysis will be performed. Please look at the help text in the form for further guidance

a. Please describe the approach for handling missing values. Will missing data be either excluded or imputed?
b. Please describe the rationale for selecting studies.
c. We noted that you are conducting a meta-analysis. Please describe how you will maintain the structure and the independence of the studies being requested in your methods (i.e., not just combining them all together and analyzing them as a single data set).
d. Please also provide the full details of all studies that you are going to analyze. You may provide the list either as an attachment or in the “Other Information” section and should include NCT or sponsor id, description of the study, and study sponsor.
e. Please also clarify if you will be bringing these studies into the Vivli research environment or if you are planning to conduct the analyses outside of the Vivli research environment and then combine the summary-level results.
f. The Vivli platform has the flexibility for you to bring in data for studies that are outside of Vivli if you have the appropriate permissions to bring that study data into the Vivli platform and you specify in your request that you want to bring the data into the platform.
g. We can help you further if we have the list of studies that you plan to include in your analyses. If you could share with us that list and update your data request, we are happy to assist you further.
Please note that this field is published on the Vivli website if the request is approved.

For additional guidance on completing your data request form, please see our video here: [https://youtu.be/Kt_ECYv2Mi8](https://youtu.be/Kt_ECYv2Mi8 "smartCard-inline")

A comprehensive listing of the software and R packages available in the Vivli Research Environment can be reviewed here: [https://vivli.org/resources/vivli-secure-research-environment/](https://vivli.org/resources/vivli-secure-research-environment/ "smartCard-inline")

If you plan to bring in additional study data, statistical tools, or scripts for use in the Vivli research environment, not included in the PDF, please list each specific tool or package in the studies section, under “Studies, Data, Tools (Not listed on Vivli)” section in the studies tab. It is Vivli’s policy that any data, statistical tools, or scripts needs to be included in this section of the data request during the review process. Requests for additional data, tools, or scripts after the review process is complete may lead to additional delays.

We kindly ask you to review the data contributors’ current data sharing policies, anonymization standards, and types of data shared on their Members Pages [https://vivli.org/members/ourmembers/](https://vivli.org/members/ourmembers/ "smartCard-inline") . The anonymization standards include detailed information about our member’s approach to anonymize the data for sharing, e.g. the AGE classification.

Please review the “Vivli policy in brief” document about active requests and active enquiries before submitting a data request: [https://vivli.org/resources/resources/](https://vivli.org/resources/resources/ "smartCard-inline")

If you have further questions, please feel free to contact us. Once the changes are made to the data request, please re-submit them for review. Thanks!

card.desc:
Study title: An Evaluation of Strategies to Accelerate Entry-into-care following HIV Diagnosis
among Adults in Gauteng and Limpopo Provinces, South Africa

‌

Dear all,

‌

I wanted to share a summary of our recent productive meeting with Salome Charalambous and Chris Hoffman, where we discussed the Heat Center project. The project aims to understand the relationship between climate data (primarily temperature) and health data in Johannesburg and Abhijan. The project requires clinical trial and cohort data sets from 2000-2022 with geolocation information, demographic information, lab data, and blood samples.

‌

During the meeting, we covered the following topics:

1. The Heat Center project: I introduced the project, outlining its main aims and the data needed.
2. Finding relevant studies: Salome and I discussed potential studies that might contribute to the project, including TB trials (especially Rifaquin), COVID trials, and HIV trials.
3. Data sharing and governance: We also talked about the process of obtaining and sharing the data, such as legal agreements and privacy assurances.

‌

The way forward for this project is as follows:

1. Identify studies with relevant data: Salome and I will work together to find suitable databases before proceeding further with the project.
2. Data sharing process: We will engage with our legal teams and data holders to establish data transfer or data sharing agreements.
3. Address potential issues: The team will discuss any concerns, such as capturing addresses electronically, with the data sharing committee before making any decisions.

‌

As an action item, I will send the presentation to Salome for the upcoming data governance meeting. In the meantime, Salome will consult with her team to determine which databases would be most suitable for the project. An intern will also be involved in moving things forward.

‌

Thank you all for your commitment to this project. We look forward to working together to achieve our goals and will keep you updated on our progress.

Best regards,

The VOICE Study – Vaginal and Oral Interventions to Control the Epidemic –is the first study to compare the safety and efficacy of oral versus topical pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for prevention of sexual transmission of HIV. VOICE is designed as a five-arm, double-blinded study in which women are first randomized to receive either gel or oral PrEP, and then within each group, randomly assigned to either tenofovir topical gel or placebo gel; or to oral tenofovir, oral Truvada or oral placebo. The study will enroll approximately 5,000 women at 15 sites in South Africa, Zimbabwe, and Uganda.

cards.desc:
Here are the main points of the study:

- The study aims to characterise the key transmissibility and clinical features of, and the antibody response to, SARS-CoV-2 in South Africa.
- The study also aims to enhance surveillance for COVID-19, identify groups at increased risk of severe illness, estimate the disease burden of medically- and non-medically attended mild, severe-non-fatal and fatal illness, and forecast the impact of the outbreak on the healthcare system and society in South Africa.
- Particular emphasis will be given to HIV-infected individuals.
- The study will achieve its aims by implementing shedding and household transmission studies, collecting sequential serum samples, enhancing facility-based (hospitals and clinics) surveillance among patients with mild and severe respiratory illness in well-established population-based surveillance sites where incidence can be calculated, and carrying out healthcare utilisation and serological surveys in selected communities.
- In addition, digital surveillance based on Google searches will be used to complement virological surveillance.
- Nowcasting and short-term forecasting (up to four weeks) will be implemented over the duration of the epidemic

- Prof Cheryl Cohen
  National Institute for Communicable Diseases, South Africa
- Prof Neil Martinson
  University of the Witwatersrand, South Africa
cards.name: Characterization of SARS-CoV-2 transmission dynamics, clinical features and disease impact in South Africa, a setting with high HIV prevalence

cards.desc:
Title: Hepatitis B Viral (Hbv) Infection

PI: Cynthia Finhaber

NB: Ian indicated that this data is nested in the Themba Lethu dataset. We will archive this card if this is confirmed.

‌

The main hypothesis of the study was to determine the prevalence of occult HBV infection in HIV-positive people in South Africa using sensitive molecular techniques for detecting HBV DNA in serum .

The study does not provide information about the age of the participants. However, it reports that 502 patients attending an urban hospital were screened for HBV using serological testing for HBsAg, core antibody (anti-HBc), and surface antibody (anti-HBs). DNA was analyzed using real-time quantitative PCR to determine the HBV viral load.

‌

doi: 10.1016/j.ijid.2008.08.018

[Occult hepatitis B virus infection in patients with isolated core antibody and HIV co-infection in an urban clinic in Johannesburg, South Africa - ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971208015415 "‌")

‌

The study, titled "A Phase IIb, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of the Safety and Immunogenicity of Ad26.Mos4.HIV in HIV-1-Negative Adults in South Africa," was published in the journal AIDS in 2008. The study was conducted by researchers from the University of KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa and the University of California, San Francisco.

The study enrolled 398 HIV-1-negative adults in South Africa. Participants were randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments:

Ad26.Mos4.HIV, a vaccine that is designed to elicit a strong immune response against HIV-1
Placebo
The primary outcome of the study was the safety of Ad26.Mos4.HIV. The study found that Ad26.Mos4.HIV was safe and well-tolerated. The most common side effects were mild and included injection site pain, fever, and fatigue.

The secondary outcome of the study was the immunogenicity of Ad26.Mos4.HIV. The study found that Ad26.Mos4.HIV elicited a strong immune response against HIV-1. The vaccine was able to generate antibodies that could neutralize HIV-1.

The study did not provide any data on how to access the data. However, the study was funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the NIH has a policy of making data from NIH-funded studies available to the public. Therefore, it is likely that the data from this study is available to the public.

cards.desc:
Title: Multicenter Adaptive SOLIDARITY - COVID-19 Clinical Trial

PI: Mohammed Siddique Rassool [mrassool@witshealth.co.za](mailto:mrassool@witshealth.co.za "‌")

The main hypothesis of the study is not explicitly stated in the abstract or the article. However, the study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of four repurposed antiviral drugs in large, randomized trials for hospitalized patients with Covid-19¹.

Source: Conversation with Bing, 2023/04/24(1) [https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184.](https://xn--www-820q.nejm.xn--org-g30q/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184. "‌") [https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184](https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2023184 "‌")  Accessed 2023/04/24.

The primary analyses examined in-hospital mortality in the four pairwise comparisons of each trial drug and its control (drug available but patient assigned to the same care without that drug). The rate ratios for death were calculated with stratification according to age and status regarding mechanical ventilation at trial entry¹.

Source: Conversation with Bing, 2023/04/24(1) [https://www.who.int/.../solidarity-clinical-trial-for-covid-19-treatments/interim-results.](https://xn--www-820q.who.xn--int-g30q/.../%EE%80%80solidarity%EE%80%81-clinical-%EE%80%80trial%EE%80%81-for-covid-19-treatments/%EE%80%80interim-results%EE%80%81. cards.desc:
## Abstract

**Background:** High BMI has been shown to be protective against tuberculosis (TB) among HIV-uninfected individuals, as well as against disease progression and mortality among those with HIV. We examined the effect of BMI on all-cause mortality and TB incidence among a cohort of HIV-infected adults in Soweto, South Africa.

**Methods:** A clinical cohort of 3456 HIV-infected adults from South Africa was prospectively followed from 2003 to 2008 with regular monitoring. The primary exposure was BMI and the outcomes of interest were all-cause mortality and a newly diagnosed episode of TB. Cox proportional hazard models assessed associations with risk of mortality or incident TB.

**Results:** Incidence rates of mortality were 10.4/100 person-years for baseline BMI of 18.5 or less, 3.6/100 person-years for baseline BMI 18.6-25, 1.7/100 person-years for baseline BMI 25.1-30, and 1.6/100 person-years for baseline BMI more than 30. Compared to those with normal BMI, overweight and obese participants had a significantly reduced risk of mortality [adjusted hazard ratio 0.59 (95% confidence interval, CI 0.40-0.87) and 0.48 (95% CI 0.29-0.80), respectively]. Incidence rates of TB by baseline BMI were 7.3/100 person-years for underweight, 6.0/100 person-years for normal, 3.2/100 person-years for overweight, and 1.9/100 person-years for obese. Compared to those with normal BMI, those with overweight and obese BMI were at a significantly reduced risk of developing TB [adjusted hazard ratio 0.56 (95% CI 0.38-0.83) and 0.33 (95% CI 0.19-0.55), respectively].

**Conclusion:** HIV-infected individuals with obese and overweight BMI have a significantly reduced risk of both mortality and TB, after adjusting for HAART use and CD4 cell count.

[https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/?term=20505496%2C21076276%2C19525621%2C19564725&format=abstract](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/?term=20505496%2C21076276%2C19525621%2C19564725&format=abstract "smartCard-inline")

cards.desc:
Liz Montgomery expressed interest in sharing these data.

Here is a summary of the study "Microbicide Ring Acceptability":

The study was conducted to evaluate the acceptability and use of a vaginal microbicide ring for HIV prevention in sub-Saharan Africa. The microbicide ring is a novel method of HIV prevention that involves the use of a ring inserted into the vagina that slowly releases an antiretroviral drug to prevent HIV infection.

The study found that the ring was generally well accepted among women in sub-Saharan Africa. The participants reported that they were comfortable using the ring and that it did not interfere with their daily activities or sexual intercourse. The ring was also found to be easy to insert and remove.

However, some participants reported concerns about potential side effects and the effectiveness of the ring in preventing HIV. There were also concerns about the ring being noticeable to sexual partners.

Overall, the study concluded that while the vaginal microbicide ring is a promising tool for HIV prevention in sub-Saharan Africa, further research is needed to address the concerns raised by the participants. This includes providing more information about the safety and effectiveness of the ring, as well as strategies to ensure that the ring is used consistently and correctly.

Please note that this is a general summary and for more detailed information, you should refer to the full study.

Dr Kartik Venkatesh [kartik.venkatesh@osumc.edu](mailto:kartik.venkatesh@osumc.edu "‌")

[https://www.rti.org/publication/degrees-disclosure-study-womens-covert-use-diaphragm-mira-hiv-prevention-trial-sub-saharan-africa](https://www.rti.org/publication/degrees-disclosure-study-womens-covert-use-diaphragm-mira-hiv-prevention-trial-sub-saharan-africa "smartCard-inline")

cards.desc:
1. **Purpose and Establishment**: The Themba Lethu Clinical Cohort was set up to facilitate large patient-level analyses from a single HIV treatment site. Its primary goal is to evaluate National Treatment Guidelines in South Africa and address questions of national and international policy relevance. It integrates economic and epidemiological perspectives into HIV research​​​​.
2. **Location and Impact**: The cohort is based at the Helen Joseph Hospital in Johannesburg. It has significantly contributed to understanding the effectiveness of HIV treatment rollout. This contribution is not only local but also extends to broader regional and national evaluations, particularly through collaborations with the International Epidemiologic Database to Evaluate AIDS (IeDEA)​​.
3. **Patient Demographics and Results**: Over time, the Themba Lethu Clinical Cohort has grown significantly. It started with less than 2,000 patients in 2004/2005 and expanded to more than 9,000 patients. The cohort, at one point, included over 13,000 patients, demonstrating positive outcomes in terms of mortality, lost to follow-up (LTF), viral suppression, and other factors over the years​​.

Trial title: A Study to Assess the Efficacy of a Heterologous Prime/Boost Vaccine Regimen of Ad26.Mos4.HIV and Aluminum Phosphate-Adjuvanted Clade C gp140 in Preventing Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) -1 Infection in Women in Sub-Saharan Africa
Study status: Completed
Study type: Phase 2b, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled
Study objective: To assess the preventive vaccine efficacy (VE) of a heterologous prime/boost vaccine regimen of Ad26.Mos4.HIV and aluminum phosphate-adjuvanted Clade C gp140 in preventing HIV-1 infection in HIV-seronegative women residing in sub-Saharan Africa.
Study population: HIV-seronegative women aged 18 to 45 years who were at high risk of HIV infection.
Interventions: Participants were randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments:
Vaccine regimen: Ad26.Mos4.HIV at Months 0 and 2, followed by aluminum phosphate-adjuvanted Clade C gp140 at Month 4
Placebo
Primary outcome: VE of the vaccine regimen against HIV-1 infection
Secondary outcomes:
Safety
Immunogenicity
The trial was conducted in 11 countries in sub-Saharan Africa and enrolled over 2,600 participants. The results of the trial showed that the vaccine regimen did not meet its primary endpoint of preventing HIV-1 infection. However, the vaccine regimen was found to be safe and well-tolerated.

The full results of the trial were published in the journal The Lancet in 2021. The study was funded by Janssen Vaccines & Prevention B.V., part of the Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson.

The Soweto-Bara Clinical Research Site was one of the 11 study sites in sub-Saharan Africa that participated in the HVTN 705/HPX2008 trial. The site was located in Soweto, South Africa, and was led by Dr. Fatima Laher. The site enrolled a total of 200 participants in the trial.

cards.desc:
VOICE trial and some PMTCT data

The VOICE PMTCT trial was a clinical research study led by Dr. Sharon Hillier that aimed to evaluate different methods of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in sub-Saharan Africa. PMTCT stands for "Prevention of Mother-To-Child Transmission" of HIV.

The trial was conducted between 2009 and 2012 and enrolled 5,029 HIV-negative women from South Africa, Uganda, and Zimbabwe who were at high risk of acquiring HIV. The participants were randomly assigned to one of five study groups: three groups received different HIV prevention methods (daily oral tablets of either tenofovir, Truvada, or tenofovir plus emtricitabine), one group received a placebo pill, and one group received a vaginal gel containing tenofovir.

The primary objective of the trial was to determine the safety and efficacy of these methods in preventing HIV transmission from mother to child during breastfeeding. However, the trial results showed that none of the methods tested were effective in reducing HIV transmission rates.

Despite these disappointing results, the VOICE PMTCT trial provided valuable insights into the challenges of implementing effective HIV prevention strategies in resource-limited settings. Dr. Hillier and her team continue to conduct important research on HIV prevention and treatment, including ongoing studies of long-acting antiretroviral drugs and novel strategies for preventing HIV transmission.

‌

NB: Thes requires HREC approval for secondary analysis. This request applies to VOICE, HOPE and ASPIRE

cards.desc:
Added as a new study based on the discussions with Ariane:

[https://www.mtnstopshiv.org/news/mtn-020-aspire](https://www.mtnstopshiv.org/news/mtn-020-aspire "smartCard-inline")

he MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial was a Phase 3, multi-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the dapivirine vaginal ring (VR) for the prevention of HIV-1 infection in healthy, sexually active, HIV-negative women. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of a dapivirine (25 mg) silicone elastomer matrix VR, inserted once every 4 weeks, in preventing HIV-1 infection and to assess its safety compared to a placebo VR.

A total of 2,629 participants were enrolled and randomized to receive either the dapivirine VR or a placebo VR. Participants used the VRs until 120 HIV-1 seroconversions were observed, with a minimum expected use of 12 months. The trial completed follow-up on June 25, 2015, and primary results were presented in February 2016, with the primary manuscript published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

**Primary Results**

The trial demonstrated that the monthly dapivirine VR was safe and effective for HIV prevention. There were no significant differences in primary safety endpoints between the study arms, and sexually transmitted infections occurred at similar rates. A total of 168 incident HIV-1 infections occurred during the product use period, with a 27% relative reduction in HIV-1 acquisition in the dapivirine ring arm compared to the placebo arm.

Subgroup analyses showed that HIV-1 protection differed significantly by age, with women ≥25 years of age demonstrating 61% protection, while those <25 years of age had no statistically significant reduction in HIV-1 incidence. Further analyses indicated that lack of HIV-1 protection and lower adherence were limited to participants ≤21 years of age.

**Study Details**

- **Protocol Chair(s):** Jared Baeten (Protocol Chair), Thesla Palanee-Phillips (Protocol Co-Chair)
- **Protocol Title:** A Multi-Center, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Phase 3 Safety and Effectiveness Trial of a Vaginal Matrix Ring Containing Dapivirine for the Prevention of HIV-1 Infection in Women
- **DAIDS Protocol ID:** 11840
- **Status:** Participants off Study and Primary Analysis Completed
- **Formulation:** Vaginal Ring
- **Drug:** Dapivirine, Placebo
- **Study Focus/Product Administration:** Vaginal
- **Study Type:** Behavioral, Efficacy, Safety
- **Study Phase:** Phase III
- **Countries:** Malawi, South Africa, Uganda, Zimbabwe
- **Population:** Women (cisgender women, non‐transgender women)
- **Funder(s):** Division of AIDS, US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, US National Institutes of Health
- **Sponsor(s):** IPM
- **Other Study Info:** Phase 3, multi-site, two-arm, randomized (1:1), double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

This summary provides an overview of the MTN-020 (ASPIRE) trial, focusing on its objectives, primary results, and key details.
